Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as dd14a9110cf16a8293d619b25ba26aa7fe1b6e2a
Can you pull in the original bbclass and add to it instead of duplicating it here?

I'm afraid that I misunderstand your meaning. Just clarify with you first.
Did you means image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass or fitimage_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass?

If it's means image type classes:
In conf/machine/include/npcm8xx.inc that include this npcm8xx image classes.
IMAGE_CLASSES:append:npcm8xx = " image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx"

In openbmc github, I find this meta-phosphor/conf/distro/include/phosphor-base.inc include this npcm7xx image classes.
IMAGE_CLASSES:append:npcm7xx = " image_types_phosphor_nuvoton"
And image_types_phosphor_nuvoton already exist in openbmc/meta-phosphor/classes/

Did you mean that I need put image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass in openbmc/meta-phosphor/classes/ this folder also? Or I need to modify image_types_phosphor_nuvoton this classes can be used by npcm7xx/npcm8xx without another image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx classes?

I was asking about fitimage_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass. image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass looks unique enough that I'm not worried about duplicating that one. You're right though that the image type class should go in meta-phosphor instead. The goal of a BSP layer should be to avoid specifics of Phosphor so that it could be used with a non-Phosphor Yocto distribution.

For the fitimage class, I was wondering if you can `require` the existing class from your new one and add the additional functionality there so that changes to the class from Yocto will get included in your new class. Otherwise it could get out of sync with changes from Yocto.

Hi Benjamin,
Thanks your reviewing and suggestion, I have checked with Joseph today.
Around half year ago, seems you already discussed with him before.

There is an alignment issue if accessing fdt binary from nor flash.
Temporary, I think that we also need your help to merge this bbclass. Eventually, this alignment fault might be fixed in the original Poky/Yocto class as you mentioned before. Without this solution, it's easy to make a fdt binary start address which is not aligned with 8 bytes in the fit-image.

[Issue symptoms]
If the fdt binary start address is not aligned of 8 bytes in the flash.
The booting process will stop after showing the console message "Loading Ramdisk". Then the synchronous abort message is shown. The ESR value is 0x96000021, after checking the Arm Architecture Reference Manual Armv8, it's the alignment fault.
The fdt64_to_cpu accesses the fdt header member and the member's address is not aligned with 8 bytes. Also the MMU memory attribute for the flash is nGnRnE. IOW, the target address needs to be aligned with the access memory width.

[Solution]
Put the fdt binary at the first position in the its file which is used to make the fit-image.

[Benjamin]
We'll probably want to fix this in the original Poky/Yocto class (adding support for 8 byte alignment) since I'm sure this won't be the only CPU to run into this problem.

Sincerely,
Tim
whitespace error
Done
Shouldn't be necessary since the primary bootloader and Linux driver are available
Done

Hi Benjamin,

We've removed below line from npcm8xx.inc and use original kernel-fitimage.bbclass instead. KERNEL_CLASSES:append:npcm8xx = " fitimage_nuvoton_npcm8xx"

For fixing alignment fault in aarch64, we need to modify kernel-fitimage.bbclass.
Thus, we try to modify it then we can boot up success without any alignment fault.

Could you help to review whether we can modify this poky/meta/classes/kernel-fitimage.bbclass to support aarch64? If you have any suggestion, welcome to discuss with us. Below is modification for you refer it. Thank you.

fitimage_assemble() {
...
+	final_offset=600
+	MKIMAGE_ARGS=""
+
+	if [ "${UBOOT_ARCH}" = "arm64" ]; then
+		MKIMAGE_ARGS="-E -p ${final_offset}"
+	fi
...
 	#
 	# Step 7: Assemble the image
 	#
-	${UBOOT_MKIMAGE} \
+	${UBOOT_MKIMAGE} ${MKIMAGE_ARGS} \
 		${@'-D "${UBOOT_MKIMAGE_DTCOPTS}"' 
...
	#
	# Step 8: Sign the image and add public key to U-Boot dtb
	#
-	${UBOOT_MKIMAGE_SIGN} \
+	${UBOOT_MKIMAGE_SIGN} ${MKIMAGE_ARGS} \

Best regards,
Tim

Hi Benjamin,

We have provided another patch set for you refer it.
This patch set remove the fitimage_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass as your suggestion.
Then we use existing kernel-fitimage.bbclass and add the additional functionality there. We have tested our aarch64 platform device can boot successful without alignment fault symptom ("Synchronous Abort" handler, esr 0x96000021).

However, we meet this kind of ci failure after this patch set.
Could you kindly help me whether is there anything I miss?

target=romulus and target=p10bmc both meet this build failure as below:

ERROR: Step ‘Archive the artifacts’ failed: no workspace for ci-openbmc/distro=ubuntu,
label=docker-builder,target=romulus #12374
ERROR: Step ‘Delete workspace when build is done’ failed: no workspace for ci-openbmc/distro=ubuntu,
label=docker-builder,target=romulus #12374
Finished: FAILURE

Thanks.
Tim

This class should be in the meta-phosphor layer instead of meta-nuvoton, similar to the existing nuvoton image class: https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-phosphor/classes/image_types_phosphor_nuvoton.bbclass

Benjamin, Thanks your suggestion.
We have put image_types_phosphor_nuvoton_npcm8xx.bbclass into meta-phosphor layer.
Please help us to review and merge it. Thank you.

Hi Benjamin,

We found that there is option -B from uboot mkimage that can fix alignment issue.
With this option that we can make image alignment and without extra npcm8xx fitimage bbclass instead of using original poky/meta/kernel-fitimage.bbclass. Could you please help to review this change again?

Thanks your great help.
Tim
the "with open()" expression will close the files automatically at the end of the code block
Thanks your review and suggestion. I've removed it. Thank you.
Will need review from someone in the OWNERS file in meta-phosphor too

Have you considered using FIP image format for packaging cortex-a35 BL31/BL32 (optee-os) / BL33 (u-boot)? meta-arm layer has neat build support to generate FIP images with fiptool and optional CoT support as per ARM TBBR.

Hi Dhananjay,
Yes, we have reviewed FIP tool carefully, but we decided not to use it because:

1. We have a security enclave processor that is in charge of loading FWs and authenticating them. The FWs of BL31, optee, uboot and bootblock don’t load and authenticate by themselves. They don’t have access to security HW and keys.

2. The FWs are loaded in a none consecutive way to memory from flash, some of them are run-once so we partially override each other memory space to save RAM.
So each FW is loaded to RAM and verified separately. They are not one chunk for us.

3. Nuvoton is using a tool called bingo: (https://github.com/Nuvoton-Israel/bingo)
To generate headers for binary files, of all types. This is a very generic tool and we use it for everything, not just BMC header images. The tool gets a binary and an xml that describe the header format and it will build a new file with a header. Later we sign the binaries including the header using opensll and merge the files to one big file for flash. The signing and merging is done by igps:
https://github.com/Nuvoton-Israel/igps-npcm8xx
which is a set of python scripts that use bingo and maintain default xml files. It also holds binaries for those who wish to program flash without compiling each FW.

4. The same tool is versatile to easily create new headers in any format.
Users get a sample of xml inside the igps, and can change values in the header easily according to their specific needs. We use it for many similar tasks, not just for TFA. We are so happy with it that we hardly ever change it when taking it from project to the next.

5. IGPS + bingo are Nuvoton tools to provide image assembling, signing, configuration and programming of our BMC products. When we decided to use TF-A, we assimilated it inside easily, we have no need to add more tools. The tools we have are already designed to match our HW

Best regards,
Tim
Thanks your question, we had reply it. Thanks.
looks good

@Dan, about meta-evb layer, we need to submit another commit for this layer.
Due to there is not only evb-npcm845.conf, but also need to add bblayers.conf.sample, distro conf and so on. Thus, we will keep evb-npcm845.conf in meta-nuvoton layer currently then move to meta-evb-npcm845 when it's ready. Thanks.
I remember the guidance has changed between putting EVB confs in meta-evb vs in BSP layers. Is this the current best practice?

I didn't know which guidance mention about this. But, I just refer to previous npcm7xx's evb-npcm750.conf in meta-nuvoton layer as below:

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-nuvoton/conf/machine/evb-npcm750.conf

And there is symbolic link in meta-evb layer that point to above meta-nuvoton's conf as below:

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-evb/meta-evb-nuvoton/meta-evb-npcm750/conf/machine/evb-npcm750.conf
../../../../../meta-nuvoton/conf/machine/evb-npcm750.conf
 
Thus, I put evb-npcm845.conf in meta-nuvoton layer also.
Should I need to create symbolic link in meta-evb layer for evb-npcm845.conf? Thanks.

> I remember the guidance has changed between putting EVB confs in meta-evb vs in BSP layers. Is this the current best practice?

In upstream BSPs (like meta-freescale) I see these in the bsp layer.  In my opinion, we should  aspire to do the same, and not put them in meta-evb.  meta-evb is just a hack to make OpenBMCs setup script work and pull in all the OpenBMC layers.

shall the machine conf put in meta-evb layer instead of this SoC meta layer?
like meta-evb/meta-evb-nuvoton/meta-evb-npcm750/conf/machine/evb-npcm750.conf
Yes, you're right. I will move this conf file into meta-evb folder. Thank you.
these image layout, serial console stuff are reference default value, to allow product machine layer to override it shall use ?=
Thanks your review. I will use "?=" instead of "=" to override it.

Hi Dhananjay,
According your suggestion in #55234, we have sync FLASH_* setting from this commit and remove it here. Thanks your review.
Looks good. Just needs the other dependent patches
Sync npcm8xxx.inc (TA_*  variables) from #55234, also need to define OPTEEMACHINE (as it's not npcm8xxx), etc.
Thanks your help to review. We will keep update and make the other dependent patches were merged.
I will update npcm8xx.inc for TFA and OPTEE. Thanks for your reminder.

What's the intention of this variable? Enable TrustZone OS (SPD)?
Previously I suggested setting TFA_SPD = opteed in this inc, but does Nuvoton BL31 require SPD to be present? e.g. if PSCI is implemented in SPD. If not, this setting could be left to the downstream layer.
This variable just using for enable/disable build TFA and OPTEE-OS. I plan to remove this variable. Thanks.
This should be in npcm8xxx.inc?
I think that could be in npcm8xx.inc. I will update if there is no any concern. Thanks.

Hi Benjamin,

Thanks your support to merge the other commits related to this commit.
Currently, #55099, #55117, #55128, #55234 and #55235 all were merged with all your help to achieve.
Could you kindly help to merge this commit also?

Thank you so much.
Tim
This has changes to meta-phosphor which I am not an owner of, so it will need a +2 from one of them (Brad Bishop, Ed Tanous, Andrew Geissler, or Patrick Williams) in addition to mine
